stem: A 58-year-old client is on Day 2 following a total knee arthroplasty. Based on the documentation in the Acute Respiratory & Perfusion Log, which finding is the most predictive of a Pulmonary Embolism (PE)?

tabs.title: Respiratory Trends
tabs.content:
Indicator0800 (Pre-incident)1000 (Now)
Resp Rate1838 (Tachypnea)
SpO298% (Room Air)84% (on 6L O2)
Breath SoundsClearClear in all lobes

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content:
Vitals: BP 82/40. HR 142. Temp 98.6.
Condition: Client reports sudden, sharp chest pain when taking a deep breath (Pleuritic pain) and extreme anxiety ('Impending Doom').

tabs.title: Post-Op Status
tabs.content: Note: Client has not ambulated since surgery due to 'significant pain.' Calf on the right leg is 4cm larger than the left and is warm to the touch.

options.text: Sudden-onset tachypnea and hypoxia with clear breath sounds
The presence of a calf size difference

rationale.correct: This is a **Pulmonary Embolism (a1)**. The most predictive clinical cue in a post-op patient is the **'Mismatch'** of severe respiratory distress/tachypnea (RR 38) and profound hypoxia (84%) while the **lungs remain clear** (a1). This happens because the 'pipes' (vessels) are blocked, but the 'balloons' (alveoli) are still empty and clear of fluid. If it were pneumonia or heart failure, you would hear crackles or wheezes. The calf size difference (a4) is a cue for a DVT, which *leads* to a PE, but the 'Mismatch' confirms the pulmonary event.
clinicalPearls: PE = Clear lungs + tachypnea + low SpO2.
V/Q Mismatch: Ventilation (V) is fine, but Perfusion (Q) is zero.
Treatment: 1. Elevate HOB. 2. Oxygen. 3. Anticoagulation (Heparin) or Thrombolytics.

questionTrap.trap: Choosing the calf size (a4) as the 'most predictive' of PE.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Calf size predicts a **DVT**. The question asks what predicts the **PE** (the event in the lungs). Always look at the system being questioned.

mnemonic.title: P-E Mismatch
mnemonic.expansion: P-Pipes are blocked. E-Empty lungs (Clear). M-Mismatch of oxygen.
